conclusion: AB is the horizontal diameter of the circular cross-section with center O and radius R, with A at the left end.
The particle starts from rest at A and moves with constant acceleration a = qE / m due to uniform electric force qE.
The trajectory of the particle is a straight line in the direction of the electric field E.
The particle starts from rest at A and leaves the field at C, with angle ∠BAC = θ = 60°.
The direction of the electric field is along AC, making 60° with AB.
Unit vector from A along AC is (cos 60°, –sin 60°) = (½, –√3⁄2).
Let the unknown length AC = s. Coordinates of C are xC = –R + ½ s and yC = –(√3⁄2) s.
Point C lies on the circle x² + y² = R². Substituting yields (–R + ½ s)² + (√3⁄2 s)² = R² ⇒ –Rs + s² = 0 ⇒ s = R.
Kinematics: starting from rest, distance travelled d = R, final speed v₀.
For constant acceleration, v₀² = 2 a d = 2 ( qE / m ) R.
Solve for E: E = m v₀² / ( 2 q R ).
Magnitude of the uniform electric field: E = m v₀² / (2 q R).
